job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Station, TX
pros: Professional Development: Being a TA provides hands-on experience in teaching and education, which can be valuable for future careers in academia or education. Networking Opportunities: Working as a TA provides the opportunity to network with faculty, other TAs, and students, which can be helpful for establishing professional connections and building your resume. Financial Benefits: TAships are typically paid positions, which can help offset the cost of tuition and provide a steady source of income while you pursue your graduate degree. Additionally, the experience and skills gained as a TA can increase your marketability and earning potential after graduation.
cons: Time Commitment: TA duties often require a significant time commitment, which can interfere with other responsibilities such as research and coursework. Workload: As a TA, you may be responsible for grading papers, holding office hours, leading discussion sections, and preparing materials for class, which can result in a heavy workload. Lack of Autonomy: As a TA, you will be working under the guidance and supervision of a professor, which may limit your ability to make decisions and take initiative in the classroom.

Reality is that salaried staff positions are rare and they open them up nationally. In the hiring process for those jobs they do not consider it a promotion from your current role, it is a National job search. They do not have loyalty to employees who put in years working toward a position- often times forced to do the role of that salaried position but for starvation wages. Starting employees can go through 3+ rounds of pay raises and still make less than an Amazon factory worker. Oh and you have to pay to park- and it is very expensive so if you do, you’re actually taking home Min. Wage (7.25).

(People tend to not get fired for anything here because that would require leadership, so many have enjoyed and will continue to enjoy getting away with a range of despicable behaviors here.) Stuck in the middle are innocent local folks who have never known anything else and who are willing to make excuses for this environment because they honestly believe that this is normal. review_title: Too little time; to do things right & for TAMU to make it right.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros:
-More than any other institution i have worked at, TAMU are smart, caring, polite, and well meaning. 

- No one works in education for money (particularly administration) and people working at TAMU care about their students. This can be very motivating

- Direct supervisors are often well educated, well intentioned, and appropriately engaged.
cons:
- Almost all of their values, goals, and what they say they offer is aspirational and not well planned. When any accountability exists, it is often a panic to achieve, not a summary of a well delivered plan.

- Zero work life balance (and you are often made to feel bad for trying to achieve any) and especially if you are working with students, that passion was leveraged against you. 

- People making decisions do not have good understanding or context to the changes they are making and, more importantly, they do not understand or acknowledge this. This is ambiguous, mostly because over the years this statement seemed to be a controlling philosophy for everything.

pros: It's a nice environment, but opinions will differ depending on which school or department you work for. Everyone I have worked with is very competent and incredibly friendly. I have gained more skills by having very helpful coworkers that are ready to answer any questions you have.
cons:
If you work for a college, be prepared to deal with massive egos. Some professors are very difficult to work with, but they are still professional if that counts for anything. Pay is not great either, but I personally found it acceptable because College Station has a very cheap cost of living.
Another big thing is internal growth. While not impossible, it is hard. Most people who get hired end up staying here for pretty much the rest of their careers. Lateral movement is much easier as you are simply switching departments, but I don't see too many opportunities for upward growth.
